title: Visalia's Kevin Downes talks about his new movie
text:
Visalia's Kevin Downes talks about his new movie James Ward , jmward@visaliatimesdelta.com 11:45 a.m. PDT October 14, 2015 “Woodlawn” tells the story of a high school football team uses religious faith to overcome racism in 1970s Birmingham, Alabama. (Photo: Pureflix) 246 CONNECT 3 TWEET LINKEDIN 1 COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
Visalia's Kevin Downes sounds like a proud father when he talks about "Woodlawn," his new movie that hits 1,600 movie screens, including theaters in Tulare County, on Friday. 
The Golden West High School and College of the Sequoias graduate called the based-on-true-events film — which he produced and has small role in — the most expensive (at $25 million) and ambitious movies he's been involved in making. 
"I think it's the best movie I've worked on," said Downes, an experienced movie writer, actor and director. "And its message about racial tolerance and love is so relevant with everything going on today." 
Downes described his role as the movie's producer as sort of the head general contractor on a building project — a combination of a problem solver, task master and ring leader of constantly moving parts. 
Downes and his brother, Bobby, have made more than a dozen films — including "Faith of Our Fathers" earlier this year, 2014's "Moms' Night Out," 2010's "Like Dandelion Dust," 2000's "Mercy Streets" with Eric Roberts and 2002's "Time Changer" — for the faith-based entertainment market. 
"Woodlawn" tells the true story of Tony Nathan, who was one of Birmingham, Alabama's first African-American star athletes in a deeply divided city that was still adjusting to integration in its public institutions and schools, including Woodlawn High School, where Nathan attended and played football Visalia native's new movie hits theaters nationwide 
The movie explores how the football team and later the community came together to at least partially overcome racial animosity and prejudice through the power of Christian faith. 
Nathan went on to be a star running back for the University of Alabama and the Miami Dolphins, winning both a NCAA national football title and a Super Bowl. 
Making the movie 
First-time actor Caleb Castille plays Nathan. 
The novice actor has surprising ties to the story, Downes said. Castille played on the 2011 and 2012 University of Alabama national championship football teams as a walk-on cornerback. Alabama's is Nathan's alma mater. 
And Castille's father, All-American Jeremiah Castille, played on legendary coach Bear Bryant's final Alabama team in the 1980s. 
The role, though, originally wasn't Castille's part. An actor from Great Britain was cast, but because of work Visa problems couldn't get into the country. Castille was a stunt double on the film. 
Downes and the rest of the creative team turned to Castille after the film's stunt coordinator raved about the young athlete turned actor.
